title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Recap: Previous Lectures âª
Lecture 1: Economics, Scarcity, Efficiency, Macro vs.Â Micro
Lecture 2: Three economic problems (WHAT, HOW, FOR WHOM) and economic systems (Market, Planned, Mixed)

ğŸ¯ Todayâ€™s Focus:
ğŸ§  How do people make economic decisions?
ğŸ¤” What is rationality?
ğŸ’° Opportunity cost â€” one of economicsâ€™ most powerful concepts!

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
What Does â€œRationalâ€ Mean? ğŸ§ 

Economic Rationality
People are rational decision-makers who seek to maximize their well-being (utility) by using cost-benefit analysis and responding predictably to incentives.


Key characteristics:
âœ… People have clear preferences
âœ… They seek to maximize their well-being (utility)
âœ… They respond predictably to incentives
âœ… They use cost-benefit analysis

ğŸ’¡ Important: Rational â‰  Perfect or emotionless! People can be rational within their information and cognitive limits (bounded rationality)

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Cost-Benefit Principle âš–ï¸

The Foundation of Rational Choice
An action should be undertaken if and only if the benefits exceed the costs.


Decision Rule:
\[\text{Decision Rule: } \begin{cases}
\text{Do it} & \text{if } Benefits \geq Costs \\
\text{Don't do it} & \text{if } Benefits < Costs
\end{cases}\]


In practice:

Benefits = What you gain
Costs = What you give up
Compare net benefit of alternatives

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Tourism Example: Cost-Benefit ğŸ›ï¸
Should a tourist visit the BelÃ©m Tower in Lisbon?


Benefits âœ…
ğŸ“· Photos & memories
ğŸ“š Educational value
â¤ï¸ Historical experience
ğŸ˜„ Satisfaction
Estimated value: â‚¬20

Costs ğŸ’¸
ğŸ« Entry ticket: â‚¬6
ğŸšŒ Travel time: 30 min
âŒ› Waiting time: 20 min
ğŸ• Value of time: â‚¬15/hr
Time cost: â‚¬12.50
Total cost: â‚¬18.50


ğŸ‘‰ Decision: Benefits (â‚¬20) > Costs (â‚¬18.50) â†’ Visit!
But if waiting time increases to 60 min, costs rise to â‚¬28.50 â†’ Donâ€™t visit!

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Decisions at the Margin ğŸ“ˆ

Marginal Analysis
Decisions are made at the margin â€” evaluating the additional benefit versus the additional cost of one more unit.


Key terms:
â¬†ï¸ Marginal Benefit (MB): Benefit from one additional unit
â¬†ï¸ Marginal Cost (MC): Cost of one additional unit


Optimal Decision Rule:
\[\text{Continue activity while } MB \geq MC\]
Stop when \(MB < MC\)

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Marginal Analysis: Hotel Rooms ğŸ¨
Should a hotel accept one more booking?

Hypothetical illustration of marginal decision-making

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
The Most Important Concept! ğŸŒŸ

Opportunity Cost
The value of the best alternative foregone when making a choice. Itâ€™s what you give up, not what you pay.


Key Points ğŸ”‘
ğŸ‘‰ Itâ€™s what you give up, not what you pay
ğŸ‘‰ Itâ€™s the next-best alternative (not all alternatives)
ğŸ‘‰ It includes both explicit (money) and implicit costs (time, foregone opportunities)

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Decision Rule with Opportunity Cost
When deciding: You should choose option A over B if:
\[\overbrace{B_A}^{\text{Gross Benefit of}\ A} \geq \underbrace{\overbrace{C_A}^{\text{Monetary Cost}} + \underbrace{(B_B-C_B)}_{\text{Surplus of best alternative}}}_{\text{Opportunity Cost of}\ A}\]

ğŸ’¡ In simpler terms: Choose A if its benefits exceed both its direct costs AND what youâ€™re giving up from the best alternative!

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Opportunity Cost Examples ğŸ’°
Simple Example: You have â‚¬100 and 4 hours free on Saturday afternoon.


Options (value, cost, time):
A. Visit museum (â‚¬15, â‚¬10, 3h)
B. Beach trip (â‚¬20, â‚¬0, 4h)
C. Movie (â‚¬22, â‚¬12, 2h)
D. Study at home (â‚¬10, â‚¬0, 4h)

If you choose A (museum):
ğŸ’¸ Explicit cost: â‚¬10
ğŸ¤” Opportunity cost: Value of best alternative foregone

Canâ€™t go to beach (value: â‚¬20)
Total opportunity cost: â‚¬10 + â‚¬20 = â‚¬30

title: Economics Fundamentals
section: Opportunity Cost in Tourism Investment ğŸ¢
text:
Opportunity Cost in Tourism Investment ğŸ¢

Hypothetical illustration of investment alternatives

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Sunk Costs: Ignore Them! ğŸš«

Sunk Cost
A cost that has already been incurred and cannot be recovered, regardless of what decision you make now. Sunk costs should be ignored in decision-making!


Examples of sunk costs:
âŒ Non-refundable deposits
âŒ Past advertising expenses
âŒ Money already spent on failed projects
âŒ Time already invested (canâ€™t get it back)

âš ï¸ Common mistake: â€œIâ€™ve already invested so much, I must continue!â€
âœ… Correct thinking: â€œWhat are my future costs and benefits from here?â€

title: Economics Fundamentals
section: Sunk Cost Example: Tourism Investment ğŸš§
text:
Sunk Cost Example: Tourism Investment ğŸš§
Scenario: Hotel construction halfway done


Spent so far (SUNK):

â‚¬2M on land
â‚¬3M on construction
Total: â‚¬5M

âŒ Cannot be recovered!

To complete (FUTURE):

â‚¬4M more needed
Expected profit: â‚¬500k/year

â“ Should you finish?


ğŸ‘‰ Correct analysis: Ignore the â‚¬5M sunk cost!
Compare: â‚¬4M future cost vs.Â future benefits
If NPV of future benefits > â‚¬4M â†’ Finish it!
If NPV of future benefits < â‚¬4M â†’ Abandon! (Donâ€™t throw good money after bad)

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Trade-offs in Tourism Policy âš–ï¸

ğŸ‘‰ Opportunity cost of increasing cultural preservation by â‚¬15M = â‚¬20M less for mass tourism infrastructure

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Making Better Decisions âœ…
Checklist for Rational Economic Decisions:
1ï¸âƒ£ Identify all alternatives
2ï¸âƒ£ Estimate benefits of each alternative
3ï¸âƒ£ Estimate costs (including opportunity costs!)
4ï¸âƒ£ Ignore sunk costs (theyâ€™re irrelevant)
5ï¸âƒ£ Consider marginal changes (not just totals)
6ï¸âƒ£ Choose alternative with highest net benefit

ğŸ’¡ Remember: Good decisions maximize net benefit (Benefits - Opportunity Costs)

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Common Decision Mistakes âŒ


Mistake 1: Ignoring opportunity costs

Thinking only about money paid
Not considering value of alternatives foregone

Mistake 2: Counting sunk costs

â€œIâ€™ve already invested so muchâ€
Looking backward instead of forward


Mistake 3: Ignoring marginal analysis

Looking at totals instead of additional units
Not considering â€œone moreâ€ decisions

Mistake 4: Not comparing net benefits

Choosing highest benefit option
But ignoring that it also has highest cost!

title: Economics Fundamentals
section: Real Business Case: Ryanair Strategy âœˆï¸
text:
Real Business Case: Ryanair Strategy âœˆï¸

ğŸ‘‰ Decision: Cancel Brussels route, add London frequency â†’ Better use of aircraft (opportunity cost logic)

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Key Concepts Summary ğŸ“‹







Concept
Definition




Rationality
People maximize well-being via cost-benefit analysis


Cost-Benefit Principle
Do it if benefits â‰¥ costs


Marginal Analysis
Decisions at the margin (additional units)


Opportunity Cost
Value of best alternative foregone


Sunk Costs
Ignore them! (already spent, irrelevant)


Trade-offs
Choosing one thing means giving up another

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Exercises ğŸ“
Practice Time!
Real-world applications of opportunity cost.

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Exercise 1: Multiple Choice
A hotel owner can use her restaurant space for:

Option A: Fine dining (â‚¬80k annual profit)
Option B: Buffet restaurant (â‚¬60k annual profit)
Option C: Rent to external operator (â‚¬50k annual rent)

She chooses Option A. What is the opportunity cost of this decision?
A. â‚¬80,000
B. â‚¬60,000
C. â‚¬50,000
D. â‚¬110,000


Answer: B (â‚¬60,000) - Opportunity cost = value of best alternative foregone. The next-best alternative to fine dining (â‚¬80k) is buffet (â‚¬60k), NOT the sum of all alternatives.

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Exercise 2: Multiple Choice
You bought a non-refundable â‚¬200 ticket to a concert. On the day of the concert, you feel ill.Â A friend offers you â‚¬50 for the ticket (transferable). What is the opportunity cost of ATTENDING the concert?
A. â‚¬200
B. â‚¬150
C. â‚¬50 + discomfort from illness
D. â‚¬250


Answer: C (â‚¬50 + discomfort) - The â‚¬200 is SUNK (canâ€™t recover even if you donâ€™t go). If you attend: you give up â‚¬50 (could sell) + endure discomfort. Opportunity cost = what you give up by attending.

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Exercise 3: Open Question
Scenario: A tour operator in Porto must decide between two summer season strategies:
Strategy A: Focus on luxury tours

Expected revenue: â‚¬500,000
Variable costs: â‚¬280,000
Fixed costs already committed: â‚¬80,000

Strategy B: Focus on budget tours

Expected revenue: â‚¬420,000
Variable costs: â‚¬200,000
Same fixed costs: â‚¬80,000

Questions:

Calculate profit for each strategy
What is the opportunity cost of choosing Strategy A?
Which strategy should be chosen and why?
Are fixed costs relevant to the decision? Explain.

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Exercise 3: Solution (Part a & b)
a) Profit calculation:
Strategy A (Luxury): \[\text{Profit}_A = â‚¬500,000 - â‚¬280,000 - â‚¬80,000 = â‚¬140,000\]
Strategy B (Budget): \[\text{Profit}_B = â‚¬420,000 - â‚¬200,000 - â‚¬80,000 = â‚¬140,000\]
Both strategies have equal profit!
b) Opportunity cost of Strategy A:
Opportunity cost = Direct Cost + Profit from best alternative foregone = â‚¬140,000 + â‚¬360,000 = â‚¬500,000  (Strategy B profit)

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Exercise 3: Solution (Part c & d)
c) Which strategy to choose?
From pure profit perspective: Indifferent (both â‚¬140,000)
But consider other factors: Risk, reputation, market trends, resource requirements
ğŸ‘‰ Recommendation: Strategy B (budget) because:

Lower variable costs (â‚¬200k vs â‚¬280k) = less risk
Higher revenue-to-variable-cost ratio: 2.1 vs.Â 1.79
More resilient to demand fluctuations

d) Are fixed costs relevant?
âŒ NO! Fixed costs (â‚¬80,000) are SUNK â€” already committed regardless of strategy choice.
âœ… Only variable costs matter for this decision (they differ between strategies).
This is a key example of ignoring sunk costs in decision-making!

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
What is Economics? ğŸ’¡

Economics studies how societies use scarce resources to produce valuable goods and distribute them among individuals.


Economics as a social science uses simplified hypotheses and relates variables to understand economic phenomena.

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
What Does Economics Study? ğŸ”


ğŸ¦ Institutions & Markets
How technology influences prices and resource allocation
ğŸ’¸ Finance
Behavior of financial markets and capital flows

ğŸ‘¥ Society
Income redistribution and social welfare
ğŸ“‰ Cycles
Unemployment, inflation, growth

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Macroeconomics ğŸ”­
The Big Picture â€” Studies the economy as a whole


ğŸ“ˆ GDP & Economic Growth
ğŸ’¼ Unemployment rates
ğŸ’° Inflation trends

ğŸ¦ Monetary policy
ğŸŒ International trade
ğŸ§¾ Government budgets


Example: â€œWhy did Portugalâ€™s tourism revenue fall 50% in 2020?â€

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Microeconomics ğŸ”¬
Individual Decisions â€” Studies specific agents and markets


ğŸ›’ Consumer behavior
ğŸ­ Firm decisions
ğŸ·ï¸ Pricing strategies

âš”ï¸ Competition analysis
ğŸ¤ Market interactions
ğŸ’¹ Supply & Demand


Example: â€œHow should a hotel set its room prices?â€

title: Economics Fundamentals
section: The Fundamental Economic Problem âš ï¸
text:
The Fundamental Economic Problem âš ï¸

Scarcity
Human wants are unlimited, but resources are limited


This leads to:
ğŸ‘‰ Trade-offs â€” Choices involve compromises
ğŸ‘‰ Cost-Benefit Analysis â€” Act only if benefits exceed costs
ğŸ‘‰ Efficiency â€” Most effective use of resources

title: Economics Fundamentals
section: Scarcity in Tourism: Lisbon Airport ğŸ›«
text:
Scarcity in Tourism: Lisbon Airport ğŸ›«


Capacity Constraints (2024)
âš ï¸ Design capacity: ~31M passengers/year
âœˆï¸ Actual 2024: ~35M passengers
ğŸ“ˆ Growing demand, limited slots
Trade-off: More flights vs.Â congestion & delays










Hypothetical illustration based on news reports

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Efficiency ğŸ¯

Economic Efficiency
Situation where the economy produces and consumes goods at socially optimal levels:
âœ… Getting the most out of available resources
âœ… Using the least for current consumption level

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Pareto Efficiency âš–ï¸
Cannot increase one personâ€™s welfare without harming another


âœ”ï¸ Efficient allocation

Resources fully utilized
No waste in production
Optimal distribution


âŒ Inefficient allocation

Resources underutilized
Production waste exists
Room for improvement

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Efficiency in Tourism ğŸ¨
Dynamic Pricing Example

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
The Three Economic Questions â“
Every economy must answer:



Question
Description
Tourism Example




WHAT?
What goods to produce?
More hotels or museums?


HOW?
How to produce them?
Automated or human agents?


FOR WHOM?
Who gets the output?
Luxury or mass tourism?




These require decisions based on: resources, technology, preferences, markets

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Positive vs.Â Normative Economics ğŸ”


Positive Economics ğŸ“Š
Describes facts â€” Can be tested

Why do managers earn more than cleaners?
Does tourism increase local incomes?
What happens to prices in high season?

ğŸ‘‰ Answered with data and analysis

Normative Economics ğŸ’­
Value judgments â€” Opinions

Should government limit Airbnb?
Should tourism revenue be redistributed?
Should airlines reduce emissions?

ğŸ‘‰ Requires ethical/political debate

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Key Concepts Summary ğŸ“‹



Concept
Definition




Economics
Study of scarce resource allocation


Macroeconomics
Whole economy (GDP, inflation)


Microeconomics
Individual decisions (firms, consumers)


Scarcity
Unlimited wants, limited resources


Efficiency
Optimal resource use (no waste)


Trade-off
Giving up one thing for another

text:
Exercises ğŸ“

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Exercise 1: Multiple Choice
Which of the following is a MACROECONOMIC question?
A. How should a hotel set its room prices?
B. Why did Portugalâ€™s tourism revenue fall in 2020?
C. Should a restaurant hire more waiters?
D. How do travelers choose between two airlines?


Answer: B â€” Portugalâ€™s tourism revenue is an aggregate measure affecting the entire economy.

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Exercise 2: Multiple Choice
A museum has limited exhibition space. Choosing between a modern art or historical exhibition illustrates:
A. Efficiency
B. Scarcity
C. Positive economics
D. Macroeconomics


Answer: B â€” Limited space (scarce resource) forces a choice between alternatives.

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Exercise 3: Open Question
Scenario: A low-cost airline charges â‚¬50/ticket, sells 150 tickets (capacity: 180).
Questions:

Calculate current revenue per flight
If price increases to â‚¬60, demand falls to 120 tickets. Calculate new revenue.
Which pricing is more efficient? Why?
Is this microeconomic or macroeconomic analysis?

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Exercise 3: Solution
a) Current revenue: \[\text{Revenue} = 50 \times 150 = â‚¬7,500\]
b) New revenue: \[\text{Revenue} = 60 \times 120 = â‚¬7,200\]
c) Efficiency:

â‚¬50 price: Revenue â‚¬7,500, occupancy 83%
â‚¬60 price: Revenue â‚¬7,200, occupancy 67%

ğŸ‘‰ First is more efficient: higher revenue AND better utilization
d) This is microeconomic analysis (individual firmâ€™s decision)

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Recap: Lecture 1 âª
Key concepts we covered:
ğŸ“ˆ Economics studies scarcity and efficiency
ğŸ”­ Macroeconomics (big picture) vs.Â ğŸ”¬ Microeconomics (individual decisions)
â“ Three fundamental questions: WHAT, HOW, FOR WHOM
ğŸ“Š Positive (facts) vs.Â ğŸ’­ Normative (values) economics

ğŸ‘‰ Today: How do different economic systems answer these questions?

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Every Society Must Solve ğŸ¤”

The Three Economic Problems
Every economy, regardless of its system, must answer three fundamental questions about resource allocation.


1. WHAT goods and services to produce?

Which products? How much of each?
Current consumption vs.Â future investment?

2. HOW to produce them?

Which technologies? Which resources?
Labor-intensive vs.Â capital-intensive?

3. FOR WHOM are goods produced?

How to distribute output?
Who gets what share of production?

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Problem 1: WHAT to Produce? ğŸ“¦


Tourism Sector Choices
ğŸ¨ Hotels & Accommodation
ğŸšŒ Transport Infrastructure
ğŸ´ Restaurants & Dining
ğŸ–ï¸ Beach Facilities
ğŸ›ï¸ Museums & Culture




ğŸ’¡ Scarce resources mean choosing between alternatives!

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Problem 2: HOW to Produce? âš™ï¸
Different Production Methods: Hotel Check-in


Traditional Method ğŸ‘¥

Human receptionists
Paper forms
Phone bookings
High labor cost
Flexible service
Personal touch

ğŸ’° Cost per check-in: ~â‚¬8-12

Automated Method ğŸ¤–

Self-service kiosks
Online booking
Mobile check-in
High capital cost
24/7 availability
Limited flexibility

ğŸ’° Cost per check-in: ~â‚¬2-4


ğŸ‘‰ Decision factors: Initial investment, labor costs, customer preferences, technology reliability

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
HOW: Production Cost Comparison ğŸ“‰

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Problem 3: FOR WHOM? ğŸ¯
Who consumes the tourism services produced?


ğŸ’¼ Business Travel
ğŸ‘ª Family Vacations
ğŸƒ Sport Tourism
ğŸŒŸ Luxury Travel

â›º Nature Tourism
ğŸ§— Adventure Travel
ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ“ Educational Tourism
ğŸŒ´ Beach Holidays


ğŸ‘‰ Distribution depends on: Income levels, prices, preferences, government policies

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
How Societies Organize Production ğŸ­

Economic System
The way a society organizes the production and distribution of goods and services to answer the three fundamental questions.


Three fundamental types:
1ï¸âƒ£ Market Economy (Laissez-faire) - Decisions by individuals and firms
2ï¸âƒ£ Centrally Planned Economy - Government makes decisions
3ï¸âƒ£ Mixed Economy (Most common today) - Combination of market and government

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Market Economy ğŸ“ˆ
Individuals and companies make key production and consumption decisions through markets


Key Features âœ…
ğŸ  Private ownership of resources
ğŸ¤ Voluntary exchange in markets
ğŸ’¸ Profit motive drives decisions
âš–ï¸ Price signals coordinate activity

The â€œInvisible Handâ€ âœ‹

No central coordinator needed
Self-interest â†’ social benefit
Competition drives efficiency
Markets allocate resources

Adam Smith, â€œThe Wealth of Nationsâ€ (1776)

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Market Economy: Advantages & Disadvantages


Advantages âœ”ï¸
ğŸš€ Efficient allocation - Resources go where most valued
ğŸ’¡ Innovation incentives - Profit rewards new ideas
ğŸ›’ Consumer sovereignty - Demand drives production
ğŸ“ˆ Flexibility - Quick adaptation to changes

Disadvantages âš ï¸
ğŸ’” Inequality - Unequal income distribution
ğŸ­ Market failures - Externalities, public goods
ğŸ’° Monopoly power - Reduced competition
ğŸŒ± Short-term focus - May ignore long-term issues

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Market Economy in Tourism âœˆï¸

Source: Eurostat (tour_occ_arnraw)

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Centrally Planned Economy ğŸ¦
Government makes key production and consumption decisions


Key Features ğŸ“‹
ğŸ¢ State ownership of resources
ğŸ’¹ Central planning authority
ğŸ§¾ Government quotas and targets
ğŸ› ï¸ Command system (not prices)

The Central Plan ğŸ—ºï¸

Government decides WHAT, HOW, FOR WHOM
5-year plans common
Quotas for production
Fixed prices

Examples: Soviet Union (historical), Cuba, North Korea

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Centrally Planned: Advantages & Disadvantages


Advantages âœ”ï¸
âš–ï¸ Equality focus - More equal distribution
ğŸŒ± Long-term planning - Can prioritize future
ğŸ›¡ï¸ Social stability - Basic needs guaranteed
ğŸš€ Rapid mobilization - Can focus resources quickly

Disadvantages âŒ
ğŸŒ Inefficiency - Information problems, no market signals
â›” No innovation - Weak incentives to improve
ğŸ˜ Consumer dissatisfaction - Limited choice, shortages
ğŸ“œ Bureaucracy - Slow, rigid decision-making

title: Economics Fundamentals
text: Centrally Planned Economy Example ğŸ¨

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Mixed Economy ğŸ¤

Mixed Economy
Combines elements of both market and centrally planned systems. Most modern economies are mixed, with varying degrees of market freedom and government intervention.


Characteristics:
ğŸ  Private & public ownership coexist
ğŸ“ˆ Markets operate but with government regulation
ğŸ›¡ï¸ Government provides public goods and services
âš–ï¸ Redistributive policies to address inequality

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Mixed Economy: The Balance :scales:
Governmentâ€™s Role in Mixed Economies


Market Activities ğŸ“ˆ
Most goods and services produced privately based on profit motive and consumer demand
Tourism example: Hotels, restaurants, tour operators

Government Activities ğŸ¢
Public goods, regulation, redistribution, addressing market failures
Tourism example: National parks, tourism promotion, safety regulations


ğŸ‘‰ The mix varies: USA (more market), Nordic countries (more government), Portugal (balanced)

title: Economics Fundamentals
section: Portugal: A Mixed Economy Example ğŸ‡µğŸ‡¹
text: Portugal: A Mixed Economy Example ğŸ‡µğŸ‡¹

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
The Inputs of Production ğŸ­

Factors of Production
The resources (inputs) used to produce goods and services. All economic systems must decide how to allocate these scarce factors.


Three main factors:
ğŸŒ¿ Land - Natural resources
ğŸ‘¥ Labor - Human effort
ğŸ¢ Capital - Produced resources
ğŸ’¡ (Some add: Entrepreneurship - organizing & risk-taking)

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Land ğŸï¸
Natural resources and raw materials


Examples ğŸŒ

Agricultural land
Energy resources (oil, gas)
Minerals and metals
Forests and water
Clean air
Climate conditions


In Tourism ğŸ–ï¸

Beaches and coastlines
Mountains and landscapes

Climate (sun, snow)
Natural parks
Geographic location

Portugalâ€™s natural assets are key tourism factors!

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Labor ğŸ‘·
Human effort - physical and mental work


Characteristics ğŸ’ª

Physical work
Mental work

Skills & education (human capital)
Time and effort spent
Experience and training


In Tourism ğŸ¨

Hotel staff and management
Tour guides
Restaurant workers
Airline crew
Event organizers

Labor-intensive industry!

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Capital ğŸ—ï¸
Produced resources used to make other goods/services


Types âš™ï¸

Physical capital: Machinery, buildings
Infrastructure: Roads, airports
Technology: Software, systems
Financial capital: Money for investment

Not the same as money - capital produces!

In Tourism âœˆï¸

Hotel buildings
Airports and airlines
Booking systems
Restaurant equipment
Transport vehicles

High capital requirements!

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Key Concepts Summary ğŸ“‘



Concept
Definition




Three Economic Problems
WHAT, HOW, FOR WHOM to produce


Market Economy
Private decisions via prices and markets


Centrally Planned
Government makes all major decisions


Mixed Economy
Combination (most common today)


Land
Natural resources used in production


Labor
Human effort (physical & mental)


Capital
Produced resources used to make goods

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Exercises ğŸ“
Time for practice!
Letâ€™s test your understanding.

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Exercise 1: Multiple Choice
In a market economy, the question â€œFOR WHOM are goods produced?â€ is primarily answered by:
A. Government planners deciding who gets what
B. Equal distribution to all citizens
C. Willingness and ability to pay
D. First-come, first-served basis


Answer: C - In market economies, goods go to those willing and able to pay for them. This is how markets allocate resources based on purchasing power.

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Exercise 2: Multiple Choice
Which of the following is an example of the CAPITAL factor of production in tourism?
A. A tour guideâ€™s knowledge and skills
B. The beach at Algarve
C. A hotel building in Lisbon
D. The managerâ€™s decision-making ability


Answer: C - The hotel building is capital (produced resource used to provide services). A is labor, B is land, D is labor/entrepreneurship.

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Exercise 3: Open Question
Scenario: The Portuguese government is considering two policies for tourism development:

Policy A: Let private investors freely build hotels wherever they want
Policy B: Government decides where hotels should be built and provides subsidies

Questions:

Identify which economic system each policy represents
List 2 advantages and 2 disadvantages of each policy
Calculate: If a private hotel costs â‚¬5M to build and generates â‚¬800k annual profit, whatâ€™s the payback period?
Recommend which policy Portugal should adopt (justify with economic reasoning)

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Exercise 3: Solution (Part a & b)
a) Economic systems:

Policy A: Market economy approach
Policy B: Centrally planned economy approach

b) Advantages and Disadvantages:







Policy A (Market)
Policy B (Planned)




âœ“ Efficient allocation (demand-driven)
âœ“ Can correct market failures


âœ“ Innovation & competition
âœ“ Ensures regional development


âœ— May ignore externalities (overtourism)
âœ— Information problems


âœ— Unequal regional development
âœ— Bureaucratic inefficiency

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Exercise 3: Solution (Part c & d)
c) Payback period calculation:
\[\text{Payback Period} = \frac{\text{Initial Investment}}{\text{Annual Profit}} = \frac{â‚¬5,000,000}{â‚¬800,000} = 6.25 \text{ years}\]
d) Recommendation: Mixed approach (combination)
ğŸ‘‰ Use market mechanism (Policy A) as primary driver - private sector is more efficient at identifying demand and driving innovation
ğŸ‘‰ Add selective government intervention (Policy B elements) - regional development incentives, environmental regulations, infrastructure investment
ğŸ’¡ This is what Portugal actually does - mostly private sector with strategic government support!

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Recap: Lecture 3 âª
Key Concepts from Last Class:
ğŸ§  Rationality: Cost-benefit decision making
ğŸ“ˆ Marginal Analysis: Decisions at the margin (MB vs MC)
ğŸ’° Opportunity Cost: Value of best alternative foregone
ğŸš« Sunk Costs: Ignore them in decisions!

ğŸ¯ Today: We build on opportunity cost to understand:

Production factors (inputs)
Production Possibilities Frontier (PPF)
Society-level trade-offs and efficiency

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
The Three Main Inputs ğŸ­

Production Factors
To produce goods and services, economies use three main factors: Land (natural resources), Labor (human effort), and Capital (produced goods used in production).



Land ğŸŒ¿

Agricultural land
Minerals & energy
Water resources
Natural beauty
Climate

Tourism: Beaches, mountains, heritage sites

Labor ğŸ‘¥

Physical work
Mental work
Skills & training
Time & effort
Entrepreneurship

Tourism: Staff, guides, managers, chefs

Capital ğŸ¢

Buildings
Machinery
Infrastructure
Technology
Equipment

Tourism: Hotels, planes, booking systems

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Factor Payments ğŸ’¸
Each factor receives compensation:








Factor
Payment Name
Example in Tourism




Land
Rent
Payment for beach concession, property lease


Labor
Wages/Salaries
Hotel staff wages, tour guide fees


Capital
Interest
Return on hotel investment, equipment loans


Entrepreneurship
Profit
Hotel ownerâ€™s profit, airline earnings

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Tourism Production: Example ğŸ“Š

Hypothetical illustration of factor intensityğŸ’¡ Insight: Cruise tourism is capital-intensive, cultural tours are labor-intensive, beach resorts balanced

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
What is the PPF? ğŸ—ºï¸

Production Possibilities Frontier (PPF)
The PPF shows the maximum combinations of two goods an economy can produce given fixed resources, current technology, and full employment.


Key Insight ğŸ’¡
With scarcity, producing more of one good requires producing less of another
â†’ This is opportunity cost visualized!

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Simple PPF Example: Tourism ğŸ–ï¸
Imagine an economy producing only:

Beach Tourism (hotels, resorts)
Cultural Tourism (museums, tours, heritage sites)

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Interpreting the PPF ğŸ”
Point A (0, 100): All resources â†’ cultural tourism, no beach tourism
Point E (100, 0): All resources â†’ beach tourism, no cultural tourism
Point C (60, 40): Mixed economy, balanced allocation
Point U (40, 30): Inefficient â€” inside PPF

Resources unemployed or misallocated
Could produce more of both goods!

Point X (80, 80): Unattainable â€” outside PPF

Not enough resources with current technology
Would need economic growth

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Moving Along the PPF â¡ï¸
From B (30, 70) to C (60, 40):
âœ… Gain: 30 units of beach tourism
âŒ Loss: 30 units of cultural tourism
ğŸ’° Opportunity Cost: 30 cultural units

Key Point ğŸ”‘

Moving along PPF = reallocation of resources
All points on PPF are efficient (no waste)
But different distributions (different answers to WHAT question)
Trade-offs are unavoidable!

title: Economics Fundamentals
section: Bowed-Out PPF: Increasing Opportunity Cost ğŸ”„
text:
Bowed-Out PPF: Increasing Opportunity Cost ğŸ”„

ğŸ’¡ Why bowed out? Resources arenâ€™t perfectly adaptable â€” some resources are better suited for beach tourism, others for cultural tourism

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Calculating Opportunity Cost on PPF :calculator:
Example: Moving from C to D


Point C: (40 beach, 92 cultural)
Point D: (60 beach, 80 cultural)
Change:

Gain: 20 beach units
Loss: 12 cultural units


Opportunity Cost:
\[OC = \frac{\text{Units Lost}}{\text{Units Gained}} = \frac{12}{20} = 0.6\]
ğŸ‘‰ Each additional beach unit costs 0.6 cultural units


Compare: D to E

Gain: 20 beach (60â†’80)
Loss: 20 cultural (80â†’60)
OC = 20/20 = 1.0 (higher!)

ğŸ’¡ Opportunity cost increases as we specialize more

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Shifting the PPF Outward ğŸš€

Economic Growth
An outward shift of the PPF represents economic growth â€” the ability to produce more of both goods. Caused by: more resources, better technology, or improved productivity.


Three ways to shift PPF outward:
â¬†ï¸ More resources (population growth, discover new land)
ğŸ’¡ Better technology (innovation, improved processes)
ğŸ“š Human capital (education, training, skills)

title: Economics Fundamentals
text: PPF Shift Example ğŸ“ˆ

title: Economics Fundamentals
section: Investment Trade-off: Present vs Future âš–ï¸
text:
Investment Trade-off: Present vs Future âš–ï¸
Key Economic Decision: Consumption today vs.Â Growth tomorrow


More Consumption Goods Today
âœ… Higher current standard of living
âœ… Immediate satisfaction
âŒ Less investment in capital
âŒ Slower future growth

More Capital Goods Today
âœ… Faster PPF outward shift
âœ… Higher future production
âŒ Lower current consumption
âŒ Sacrifice today for tomorrow


ğŸ’¡ Tourism Example: Build hotels now (consume less) â†’ More capacity future â†’ Higher tourism revenue later

title: Economics Fundamentals
text: Investment Trade-off Visualization ğŸ’°

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Tourism Investment Example ğŸ¨

ğŸ‘‰ Strategic choice: Prioritize long-term growth (infrastructure, digital) despite lower immediate returns

title: Economics Fundamentals
text: Technological Change Example ğŸ’»

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
PPF Summary: Key Insights ğŸ“‘
1ï¸âƒ£ Shows maximum production given resources & technology
2ï¸âƒ£ Points on PPF = efficient (canâ€™t produce more without trade-off)
3ï¸âƒ£ Points inside PPF = inefficient (unemployment, waste)
4ï¸âƒ£ Points outside PPF = impossible (currently unattainable)
5ï¸âƒ£ Moving along PPF = reallocating resources (opportunity cost)
6ï¸âƒ£ Shifting PPF outward = economic growth (more resources, better technology)
7ï¸âƒ£ Investment trade-off = consumption today vs.Â growth tomorrow

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Real-World Applications ğŸŒ
PPF thinking helps answer:
â“ Should Portugal build more hotels or preserve more heritage sites?
â“ How much should airlines invest in fuel efficiency vs.Â passenger comfort?
â“ Trade-off between mass tourism revenue and sustainable tourism?
â“ How much GDP to allocate to tourism vs.Â other sectors?

ğŸ’¡ All involve opportunity costs and efficiency considerations!

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Complete Picture: Integration ğŸ§©
Todayâ€™s Lecture Integration:
1ï¸âƒ£ Production Factors (Land, Labor, Capital) are scarce inputs
2ï¸âƒ£ Scarcity forces choices between alternatives
3ï¸âƒ£ PPF visualizes societyâ€™s production possibilities
4ï¸âƒ£ Opportunity Cost = moving along PPF (whatâ€™s foregone)
5ï¸âƒ£ Efficiency = operating on (not inside) PPF
6ï¸âƒ£ Economic Growth = PPF shifts outward
7ï¸âƒ£ Investment today enables faster growth tomorrow

ğŸ”— This connects to: Lecture 3 (opportunity cost), Lecture 2 (WHAT/HOW/FOR WHOM), Lecture 1 (scarcity & efficiency)

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Exercises ğŸ“
Application Time!
PPF and opportunity cost calculations.

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Exercise 1: Multiple Choice
An economy is producing at a point INSIDE its PPF. This indicates:
A. The economy is efficiently using all resources
B. The economy has economic growth
C. There is unemployment or resource misallocation
D. Itâ€™s impossible to produce more of any good


Answer: C - Inside PPF means inefficiency â€” resources are unemployed or misallocated. Could produce more of at least one good without sacrificing the other (move toward frontier).

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Exercise 2: Multiple Choice
A countryâ€™s PPF shifts outward. This could be caused by:
A. Higher unemployment
B. Decrease in the labor force
C. Technological innovation
D. Producing less capital goods


Answer: C - Outward PPF shift = economic growth. Caused by: more resources, better technology, improved productivity. Options A, B, D would shift PPF inward or cause movement inside PPF.

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Exercise 3: Open Question - Setup
Scenario: The Portuguese Algarve region has limited land and labor. It can allocate resources between golf tourism and beach tourism. Current production possibilities:



Combination
Golf Resorts
Beach Hotels




A
0
50


B
5
48


C
10
44

15
38

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Exercise 3: Questions
Questions:

Draw the PPF with Golf Resorts on x-axis, Beach Hotels on y-axis
Calculate the opportunity cost of moving from:

Point B to Point C
Point D to Point E

Does the PPF exhibit increasing opportunity costs? Explain.
If region currently operates at point U (12 golf, 30 beach), what does this indicate?
A new tourism development technology is invented. How would this affect the PPF? Draw the new curve.

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Exercise 3: Solution - Part a (PPF Graph)

a) The PPF shows all efficient combinations (points A-F) and the bowed-out shape indicating increasing opportunity costs.

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Exercise 3: Solution - Part b
b) Opportunity Cost Calculations:
B â†’ C (5 golf â†’ 10 golf): \[\text{Gain in Golf} = 10 - 5 = 5 \text{ resorts}\] \[\text{Loss in Beach} = 48 - 44 = 4 \text{ hotels}\] \[\text{Opportunity Cost} = \frac{4 \text{ hotels}}{5 \text{ resorts}} = 0.8 \text{ beach hotels per golf resort}\]

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Exercise 3: Solution - Part b continued
D â†’ E (15 golf â†’ 20 golf): \[\text{Gain in Golf} = 20 - 15 = 5 \text{ resorts}\] \[\text{Loss in Beach} = 38 - 30 = 8 \text{ hotels}\] \[\text{Opportunity Cost} = \frac{8 \text{ hotels}}{5 \text{ resorts}} = 1.6 \text{ beach hotels per golf resort}\]

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Exercise 3: Solution - Part c & d
c) Increasing Opportunity Costs?
YES! Opportunity cost increases from 0.8 (Bâ†’C) to 1.6 (Dâ†’E).
Explanation: As more resources shift to golf, we use resources less suited for golf (originally better for beaches). Each additional golf resort requires sacrificing more beach hotels.
d) Point U (12 golf, 30 beach):
This is INSIDE the PPF (compare to point D: 15 golf, 38 beach).
Indicates:

Inefficiency (unemployment or resource misallocation)
Could produce more golf without reducing beach (move to D: 15 golf, 38 beach)
Could produce more beach without reducing golf

title: Economics Fundamentals
text:
Exercise 3: Solution - Part e
e) New Technology Effect:
Technology shifts PPF OUTWARD (economic growth).
New PPF might be:



Combination
Golf Resorts
Beach Hotels




Aâ€™
0
60 (+10)


Câ€™
12
55 (+11)


Eâ€™
24
38 (+8)


Fâ€™
30
0 (+5)



Effect: Can now produce MORE of both types of tourism with same resources!
Graph: Draw original PPF, then new PPF further from origin (parallel or biased depending on where technology applies).

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Recap: Fundamentals Block âª

What we covered in Lectures 1â€“4:

Scarcity forces choices â¡ï¸ trade-offs everywhere
Economic Systems: Market, Centralized, Mixed
Opportunity Cost = accounting cost + surplus of the best alternative
PPF: Visualizes societyâ€™s production trade-offs and efficiency

Today: We zoom in from society to the individual consumer
ğŸ‘‰ How does a single person decide what to buy?

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Welcome to Consumer Theory ğŸ›’

The Big Question: Given limited income and market prices, what can a consumer afford?


Lectures 5â€“9 Roadmap:

ğŸ‘‰ Budget Set & Constraint (today)
Preferences & Rationality Axioms
MRS, Utility & Maximization
Individual & Market Demand
Demand Elasticity


Why it matters for tourism âœˆï¸
Tourists are consumers! Understanding budget constraints explains:

Why some choose hostels, others choose resorts
How exchange rates affect travel decisions
Why â€œall-inclusiveâ€ packages exist

title: Consumer Theory
section: Starting Point: What Can You Afford? ğŸ’¸
text:
Starting Point: What Can You Afford? ğŸ’¸

Every consumer faces three constraints:


ğŸ’° Income (\(M\))
The total money available to spend

ğŸ·ï¸ Price of Good 1 (\(p_1\))
How much each unit of good 1 costs

ğŸ·ï¸ Price of Good 2 (\(p_2\))
How much each unit of good 2 costs


The Consumerâ€™s Problem
Given income \(M\) and prices \(p_1\), \(p_2\), what combinations of goods 1 and 2 can the consumer purchase?

title: Consumer Theory
text:
A Tourism Example ğŸŒ´

Scenario: A tourist arrives in Lisbon with a daily budget of â‚¬100.


Two â€œgoodsâ€ to spend on:

ğŸ´ Meals at restaurants: â‚¬20 each
ğŸ« Museum tickets: â‚¬10 each

Question: What combinations of meals and museum visits can this tourist afford?




Meals (\(x_1\))
Museums (\(x_2\))
Total Spent




0
10
â‚¬100


1
8
â‚¬100


2
6
â‚¬100


3
4
â‚¬100


5
0
â‚¬100

title: Consumer Theory
text:
The Budget Constraint Equation ğŸ“

The consumer spends all income on two goods:
\[\underbrace{p_1 \cdot x_1 + p_2 \cdot x_2}_{Expenditure} = \underbrace{M}_{Budget}\]
From our example: â‚¬20 \(\cdot x_1\) + â‚¬10 \(\cdot x_2\) = â‚¬100
Solving for \(x_2\) (to graph it):
\[x_2 = \frac{M}{p_2} - \frac{p_1}{p_2} \cdot x_1\]
\[x_2 = \frac{100}{10} - \frac{20}{10} \cdot x_1 = 10 - 2x_1\]

title: Consumer Theory
text: Graphing the Budget Constraint ğŸ“‰

title: Consumer Theory
section: Key Elements of the Budget Constraint
text:
Key Elements of the Budget Constraint



Intercepts (maximum of each good):

Vertical (\(x_1 = 0\)): \(\frac{M}{p_2} = \frac{100}{10} = 10\) museums
Horizontal (\(x_2 = 0\)): \(\frac{M}{p_1} = \frac{100}{20} = 5\) meals


Slope of the budget line:
\[\text{Slope} = -\frac{p_1}{p_2} = -\frac{20}{10} = -2\]
ğŸ‘‰ For every 1 extra meal, the tourist gives up 2 museum visits
This is the economic rate of substitution set by the market! Also known as the opportunity cost of an extra meal!

title: Consumer Theory
section: Budget Set vs Budget Line ğŸ—ºï¸
text:
Budget Set vs Budget Line ğŸ—ºï¸


Budget Line vs Budget Set

Budget Line All bundles where the consumer spends exactly all income: \(p_1 x_1 + p_2 x_2 = M\)
Budget Set All affordable bundles (spend all or less): \(p_1 x_1 + p_2 x_2 \leq M\)

The budget set is the shaded area including the line itself.

Bundles above the budget line are unaffordable âŒ
Bundles on the budget line: spend all income âœ…
Bundles inside the budget set: affordable with money left over âœ…

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Change in Income ğŸ“ˆ

What happens if our touristâ€™s budget increases from â‚¬100 to â‚¬150?



ğŸ‘‰ Income change: parallel shift (slope unchanged at \(-p_1/p_2\))

title: Consumer Theory
section: Change in Price of Good 1 ğŸ·ï¸
text:
Change in Price of Good 1 ğŸ·ï¸

What if meal prices drop from â‚¬20 to â‚¬10?



ğŸ‘‰ Price change of one good: pivot around the other intercept (slope changes!)

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Summary: What Shifts What? ğŸ“










Change
Effect on Budget Line
Slope
Intercepts




â¬†ï¸ Income (\(M\))
Parallel shift outward
Same
Both increase


â¬‡ï¸ Income (\(M\))
Parallel shift inward
Same
Both decrease


â¬‡ï¸ Price \(p_1\)
Pivot outward on \(x_1\) axis
Flatter
\(x_1\)-intercept increases


â¬†ï¸ Price \(p_1\)
Pivot inward on \(x_1\) axis
Steeper
\(x_1\)-intercept decreases


â¬‡ï¸ Price \(p_2\)
Pivot outward on \(x_2\) axis
Steeper
\(x_2\)-intercept increases


â¬†ï¸ Price \(p_2\)
Pivot inward on \(x_2\) axis
Flatter
\(x_2\)-intercept decreases




ğŸ’¡ Key insight: The slope \(-p_1/p_2\) is the relative price â€” what the market says one good costs in terms of the other.

title: Consumer Theory
section: The Slope as Opportunity Cost âš–ï¸
text:
The Slope as Opportunity Cost âš–ï¸

The slope of the budget constraint has a direct economic interpretation:
\[\text{Slope} = -\frac{p_1}{p_2}\]
This tells us the marketâ€™s exchange rate between the two goods.


Our example: \(-20/10 = -2\)
For 1 extra meal, you must give up 2 museum visits.
This is not a preference â€” it is a constraint imposed by prices!

ğŸ‘‰ Compare with the PPF slope from Lecture 4

PPF slope: societyâ€™s opportunity cost (technology)
Budget line slope: individualâ€™s opportunity cost (prices)

Both represent trade-offs, at different scales!

title: Consumer Theory
section: Application: Exchange Rates & Tourist Budgets ğŸ’¶
text:
Application: Exchange Rates & Tourist Budgets ğŸ’¶

How exchange rates shift a touristâ€™s budget constraint
A British tourist visits Portugal with Â£500 to spend on:

ğŸ¨ Accommodation: â‚¬80/night
ğŸ´ Dining: â‚¬20/meal




Scenario A: Â£1 = â‚¬1.15
Budget in â‚¬: Â£500 Ã— 1.15 = â‚¬575

Max nights: 575/80 â‰ˆ 7.2
Max meals: 575/20 â‰ˆ 28.8


Scenario B: Â£1 = â‚¬1.30
Budget in â‚¬: Â£500 Ã— 1.30 = â‚¬650

Max nights: 650/80 â‰ˆ 8.1
Max meals: 650/20 â‰ˆ 32.5


ğŸ‘‰ A stronger pound = parallel outward shift of the budget constraint in euro terms. The tourist can afford more of everything!

title: Consumer Theory
section: Application: All-Inclusive vs.Â Ã€ La Carte ğŸ¨
text:
Application: All-Inclusive vs.Â Ã€ La Carte ğŸ¨

Why do all-inclusive packages exist?


Ã€ la carte (standard budget constraint):

Tourist allocates budget freely between accommodation and experiences
Faces standard linear budget line
Trade-offs are clear: more luxury room = fewer excursions


All-inclusive package:

Fixed price for a bundle (room + meals + activities)
Effectively removes the trade-off within the bundle
Budget constraint becomes a single point for included goods
Remaining budget: free for souvenirs, extra trips, etc.


ğŸ’¡ All-inclusive packages simplify the consumerâ€™s problem by pre-selecting a bundle. Weâ€™ll revisit this when we study preferences in Lecture 6!

title: Consumer Theory
section: Numerical Example: Step by Step ğŸ§®
text:
Numerical Example: Step by Step ğŸ§®

Problem: A tourist has â‚¬200 to spend. Surfing lessons cost â‚¬40 each. Fado show tickets cost â‚¬25 each.
Step 1: Write the budget constraint
\[40 x_1 + 25 x_2 = 200\]
Step 2: Find intercepts

If \(x_1 = 0\): \(x_2 = 200/25 = 8\) fado shows
If \(x_2 = 0\): \(x_1 = 200/40 = 5\) surf lessons

Step 3: Find the slope
\[\text{Slope} = -\frac{p_1}{p_2} = -\frac{40}{25} = -1.6\]
ğŸ‘‰ 1 extra surf lesson costs 1.6 fado shows
Step 4: Check an interior bundle â€” (2 surf, 4 fado): \(40(2) + 25(4) = 80 + 100 = 180 \leq 200\) âœ… (inside budget set, â‚¬20 unspent)

title: Consumer Theory
text:
General Formulas: Cheat Sheet ğŸ“‹


Budget Constraint Formulas
Equation: \(p_1 x_1 + p_2 x_2 = M\)
Solved for \(x_2\): \(\displaystyle x_2 = \frac{M}{p_2} - \frac{p_1}{p_2} x_1\)
Vertical intercept (\(x_1 = 0\)): \(\displaystyle \frac{M}{p_2}\)
Horizontal intercept (\(x_2 = 0\)): \(\displaystyle \frac{M}{p_1}\)
Slope: \(\displaystyle -\frac{p_1}{p_2}\) (the relative price of good 1 in terms of good 2)

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Summary: Todayâ€™s Key Takeaways

Todayâ€™s Lecture Integration:

Income (\(M\)) and prices (\(p_1, p_2\)) define the consumerâ€™s constraint
Budget line: \(p_1 x_1 + p_2 x_2 = M\) â€” all bundles spending exactly all income
Budget set: \(p_1 x_1 + p_2 x_2 \leq M\) â€” all affordable bundles
Slope = \(-p_1/p_2\) = market rate of exchange between goods
Income changes â¡ï¸ parallel shift
Price changes â¡ï¸ pivot (rotation)

Connection to previous lectures: The budget line is the individual-level analog of the PPF â€” both show feasible combinations and trade-offs.
Next: Lecture 6 â€” Consumer Preferences and axioms of rationality. Weâ€™ll ask: among all affordable bundles, which one does the consumer actually want?

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Exercises
Application Time! âœï¸
Budget constraint calculations and graphical analysis.

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Exercise 1: Multiple Choice

Question: A consumer has income \(M = 120\), with \(p_1 = 15\) and \(p_2 = 10\). The slope of the budget constraint is:
A. \(-10/15\)
B. \(-15/10\)
C. \(-120/15\)
D. \(-120/10\)


Answer: B

The slope of the budget line is always \(-p_1/p_2 = -15/10 = -1.5\). This means for each additional unit of good 1, the consumer must give up 1.5 units of good 2. Note: income affects the position of the line, not its slope.

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Exercise 2: Multiple Choice

Question: If the price of good 2 doubles while income and \(p_1\) stay the same, the budget line:
A. Shifts outward in parallel
B. Pivots inward around the \(x_1\)-intercept
C. Pivots outward around the \(x_2\)-intercept
D. Pivots inward around the \(x_2\)-intercept


Answer: B

When \(p_2\) doubles: the \(x_2\)-intercept (\(M/p_2\)) halves (moves down), while the \(x_1\)-intercept (\(M/p_1\)) stays the same. So the line pivots inward around the \(x_1\)-intercept. The consumer can buy less of good 2 but the same maximum of good 1. The slope \(-p_1/p_2\) becomes smaller in absolute value (the line becomes flatter).

title: Consumer Theory
text:
Exercise 3: Open Question

Scenario: A Portuguese tourism student plans a weekend trip. She has a budget of â‚¬150. She wants to split spending between:

ğŸ„â€â™€ï¸ Surf lessons: â‚¬30 each (\(x_1\))
ğŸ· Wine tasting tours: â‚¬25 each (\(x_2\))

Questions:

Write the budget constraint equation and solve for \(x_2\).
Calculate and interpret the slope. What is the opportunity cost of one surf lesson in terms of wine tastings?
Find both intercepts. Draw the budget constraint with \(x_1\) on the horizontal axis.
Is the bundle (2 surf lessons, 3 wine tastings) affordable? Is it on the budget line?
Suppose the student receives a â‚¬50 gift card (total budget now â‚¬200). Draw the new budget line on the same graph. What changed and what stayed the same?
Now instead of the gift card, suppose surf lesson prices drop to â‚¬25 (budget stays at â‚¬150). Draw this new line. How does it differ from part (e)?

title: Consumer Theory
section: Exercise 3: Solution â€” Parts a, b, c
text:
Exercise 3: Solution â€” Parts a, b, c

a) Budget constraint: \(30x_1 + 25x_2 = 150\)
Solving for \(x_2\): \(x_2 = \frac{150}{25} - \frac{30}{25}x_1 = 6 - 1.2x_1\)
b) Slope \(= -p_1/p_2 = -30/25 = -1.2\)
ğŸ‘‰ Each surf lesson costs 1.2 wine tastings. The opportunity cost of 1 surf lesson is 1.2 wine tours foregone.
c) Intercepts:

\(x_1 = 0 \Rightarrow x_2 = 150/25 = 6\) wine tastings (vertical intercept)
\(x_2 = 0 \Rightarrow x_1 = 150/30 = 5\) surf lessons (horizontal intercept)

Graph: straight line from \((0, 6)\) to \((5, 0)\).

title: Consumer Theory
section: Exercise 3: Solution â€” Parts d, e, f
text:
Exercise 3: Solution â€” Parts d, e, f

d) Bundle (2, 3): \(30(2) + 25(3) = 60 + 75 = 135 \leq 150\) âœ…
Affordable? Yes! On the budget line? No â€” she spends only â‚¬135, leaving â‚¬15 unspent. The bundle is inside the budget set.
e) New budget â‚¬200: \(30x_1 + 25x_2 = 200 \Rightarrow x_2 = 8 - 1.2x_1\)

New intercepts: \((0, 8)\) and \((6.67, 0)\)
Parallel shift outward â€” slope unchanged at \(-1.2\)

f) Price drop \(p_1 = 25\), \(M = 150\): \(25x_1 + 25x_2 = 150 \Rightarrow x_2 = 6 - x_1\)

New intercepts: \((0, 6)\) and \((6, 0)\)
Pivot outward around vertical intercept â€” slope changes to \(-1\)

Key difference: (e) is a parallel shift (more of both goods equally); (f) is a pivot (relatively more surf lessons become affordable, wine tasting maximum unchanged).
